awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Observational and Numerical Modeling Studies of Rain Microphysics
awd_abstract_narration:
Since 1988, the US National Weather Service has operated a network of around 160 advanced Doppler weather radars for monitoring severe weather and issue warnings, for example, of tornadoes, flash-floods, etc. The last major upgrade of these radars occurred in 2013 involving dual-polarization capability which greatly enhances the ability to detect flash-flood producing storms and extreme rainfall from land-falling hurricanes. This project seeks to improve the measurement accuracy of rainfall by such radars using advanced instruments that measure the properties of individual rain drops such as size, shape, concentration and fall speeds. From knowledge of these properties in different rain intensities and types, the algorithms for radar estimation of rainfall rates can be developed with greater accuracy than possible hitherto. In parallel, numerical models that use detailed microphysics of rain formation and evolution are being compared against radar observations to verify that the physical representation and assumptions in the numerical models are indeed correct. This is difficult because heavy rain at the surface originates from many sources aloft at colder temperatures within the storm and it evolves in a complex manner as the drops reach the surface. Thus, the integration of radar measurements with surface rain properties and numerical models is an essential component of this research which is likely to result in improved accuracy of warnings of flood-producing storms issued by the National Weather Service. 

The main scientific goal of this project is to obtain a deeper understanding of microphysical processes governing the evolution of drop size distributions (DSDs) using a synergistic combination of dual-polarization radar retrievals of DSD moments and one-dimensional (1D) model-predictions of moments and process rates for well-observed cases by the scanning polarimetric C-band ARMOR radar and the Mobile Integrated Profiling System (MIPS) operated by the University of Alabama at Huntsville (UAH). The simulations are based on two new numerical models, (i) the cloud particle model (CPM) developed at the University of Oklahoma which explicitly accounts for the evolution of all the cloud particles under warm rain microphysical processes, and (ii) a novel Monte-Carlo microphysics model (McSnow) developed by the German Weather Service that simulates the evolution of ice, mixed phase and rain based on the physical properties of "super-particles". Three different instruments will be used to measure and characterize the DSDs over the entire range of sizes from 0.1-8 mm with good accuracy (Meteorological Particle Spectrometer, 2D-video disdrometer, and Precipitation Occurrence Sensor System). Simultaneously, the volume above the instruments will be scanned by the dual-pol ARMOR radar as well as MIPS. The two particle models will be run in 1D and the DSD evolution will be compared against surface measurements and radar profiles to infer the dominant microphysical processes that shape the DSD. The coupling between ice processes above the melting level to rain processes below the melting level to the surface needs to be better understood. McSnow-predicted profiles and slopes of dual-pol variables with height from above the bright-band to the surface will be compared with radar observations to infer the dominant processes as well as rain types. Surface measurements will serve as constraints to the model predictions.

One central assumption in nearly all collisional process modeling is that raindrops fall at terminal velocity depending only on the drop mass. However, some recent observations of fall speed distributions show that under turbulent conditions, mm-sized drops can deviate significantly from the Gunn-Kinzer terminal velocity equation which needs to be confirmed. The explicit cloud particle model will be used to predict if there is a significant impact of turbulence-induced fall speed deviations (mean and variance) on collisional processes and subsequently on DSD evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes or findings: Clouds represent a major source of uncertainty in climate models and improvements in modeling of cloud microphysical processes impact a wide range of fields from numerical weather prediction and radar retrievals to hydrology. Currently, satellite platforms use cloud models based on bulk schemes to generate statistics for precipitation retrieval algorithms. The droplet size distribution (DSD) assumed by these applications follows an exponential distribution which doesn’t match the observed DSDs from ground-based or airborne observations. Therefore, improved understanding of DSDs and their dependence on environmental conditions is critical to enhancing the accuracy of climate modeling, hydrological modeling, and radar remote sensing. However, this necessitates a robust understanding of the underlying mechanisms that affect the DSDs, which has motivated our proposed work. 

Supported by NSF, we have developed, validated and applied a new particle-based cloud model for directly simulating the growth of cloud and rain drops under various microphysical processes, such as diffusional growth, collision-coalescence, and spontaneous and collision-induced breakup. This model is different from previous cloud modeling approaches in that it uses the limited volume interaction method to reduce computational cost. It has the main advantage of retaining the stochastic nature of particle-particle interactions without having to introduce any mean field theory. Moreover, our new Cloud Particle Model (CPM) is more sensitive to random fluctuations than the super droplet method, a desirable feature for studying random variation in fall speeds. To validate the CPM, a series of experiments have been conducted to compare its performance with analytic solutions or classical simulations from previous studies. Our results indicate the CPM is a viable model for testing various microphysical methods and can serve as a benchmark for more computationally efficient modeling methods.  

Motivated by recent observations that hydrometeors exhibit non-terminal fall speeds, we further applied the CPM model through a series of sensitivity studies to investigate how the non-terminal fall speeds affect the collision, coalescence and breakup of raindrops. We found there was a critical width of the velocity variations, which if not exceeded, resulted in approached equilibrium distributions that were statistically indistinguishable from the equilibrium distributions approached using the deterministic terminal velocities. The exact value of this critical standard deviation depends strongly on the assumed initial distribution. Moreover, the accelerating effect of turbulence has a greater impact on the number concentration of large particles, while the decelerating effect of turbulence has a greater impact on the number concentration of small particles. Our work has also identified specific observational parameters that could be targeted by future observational studies to better constrain the assumptions used in models, thus advancing our ability to reducing uncertainties in climate models, numerical weather prediction and radar remote sensing. 

Science Impact: As more complex bulk microphysical schemes at higher resolutions are continually being incorporated within Weather Research and Forecasting Model (WRF), our particle-based microphysical models along with detailed observations provide benchmarks for evaluation of bulk microphysical schemes’ treatment of warm rain processes, in particular, evaporation, collision, coalescence, and breakup, many of which involve stochastic processes. Validation of our model predictions actually moves beyond just comparing with radar reflectivity and surface rain accumulations to comparison with radar-retrievals of lower-order moments both at the surface and in the rain layer. Drop size distributions and their variability are central to dual-pol and attenuation-based radar retrievals of rainfall. The detailed model output can also be used for training of data-driven microphysical parameterizations using deep learning approaches. Our work on drop shapes and drop oscillations is relevant to the radio wave community, specifically to quantify the effects of rainfall on microwave and millimeter-wave communication systems, including rain attenuation for horizontal and vertical polarization and depolarization effects for systems using polarization diversity. The DSD characterization and fall speed measurements are directly related to the kinetic energy of raindrops which is important for soil erosion and runoff rates and ultimately to changes in, for example, the coastal ecosystem.

Educational Impact: As the educational component of this project, a graduate student (Logan M. Roy) has been successfully trained to be next-generation scientist on cloud physics. Scientific findings resulted from this project have been disseminated by former PI (Dr. Wei Wu) and current PI (Dr. Feng Xu) in two core graduate courses taught at University of Oklahoma, including METR-5233 - Cloud and Precipitation Physics and METR 5223 - Atmospheric Radiation. In addition, our research outcome and findings have also been documented into Logan Roy’s thesis, journal publication and disseminated to the communities of radar remote sensing, hydrology, and cloud physics through former PI and student’s attending multiple domestic and international conferences.
